intro: Acer campestre, commonly known as the field maple, is a deciduous tree or shrub native to Europe and western Asia. It typically grows to a height of 5–10 meters, featuring a broad, rounded crown and smooth, gray-brown bark. The leaves are palmately lobed, with five to seven pointed lobes, and turn vibrant yellow in the autumn. It produces small, yellowish-green flowers in early spring, followed by winged seeds called samaras. This plant thrives in well-drained soils and is often found in woodland edges, hedgerows, and open areas.
taxonomy_art_desc: Acer campestre belongs to the kingdom Plantae. Its phylum is Streptophyta, which includes all land plants and is characterized by the presence of true roots, stems, and leaves. Its class is Equisetopsida, which encompasses vascular plants with a diverse range of forms, including ferns and horsetails. Its subclass is Magnoliidae, a group of flowering plants that includes many economically important species. Its order is Sapindales, a group of flowering plants that includes trees and shrubs with showy flowers. Its family is Sapindaceae, commonly known as the soapberry family, which includes a variety of tropical and temperate species. Its genus is Acer, which consists of deciduous trees and shrubs commonly known as maples, known for their distinctive leaves and colorful autumn foliage. Its species is Acer campestre, commonly known as the field maple, a small to medium-sized tree native to Europe and parts of Asia.
distribution_native_art_desc: Acer campestre is primarily native to Albania, Algeria, Austria, Belarus, Belgium, Bulgaria, Corse, Czechia-Slovakia, Denmark, France, Germany, Great Britain, Greece, Hungary, Iran, Italy, Krym, Netherlands, North Caucasus, NW. Balkan Pen., Poland, Romania, Sardegna, Sicilia, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Transcaucasus, Türkey, Türkey-in-Europe, Ukraine, and Uzbekistan. This species is commonly found in a wide range of habitats, including woodlands, hedgerows, and open areas. It is well adapted to temperate climates and can thrive in both urban and rural environments. The plant is known for its ornamental value, with its distinctive leaves and small, red berries. Its broad native distribution reflects its ability to colonize various ecological niches across Europe and parts of Asia.
distribution_introduced_art_desc: Acer campestre was mainly introduced to California, Central European Russia, Connecticut, East European Russia, Illinois, Indiana, Ireland, Kazakhstan, Kentucky, Maryland, Massachusetts, Michigan, New Jersey, New York, North Carolina, Ohio, Ontario, Pennsylvania, Portugal, Prince Edward Island, Rhode Island, South European Russia, Tajikistan, Turkmenistan, Vermont, Virginia, and West Virginia. It has been established in a wide range of regions across North America and Europe. The plant is commonly found in temperate climates with well-drained soils. It is often used in landscaping due to its ornamental value and adaptability. Its introduction to these areas has led to its naturalization in many of these regions.
